narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my writing skills, logical thinking skills, and reading skills in terms of how to read a paper for its argument.
I learned how to write clearly and simply. I gained the skills of reaching the broadest possible audiences given my essay topic.

I learned how to read and extract information from a research paper, and how to reconstruct a paper's argument. I also learned what kind of writing college papers ask for, and what high school writing strategies or rules that I needed to unlearn.
This class gave me a great introduction to academic and college writing.

This class was excellent in prepping me on the actual structure of academic writing. I feel all the more prepared for academic papers in future courses. This class also helped me learn to come up with novel ideas, and I feel much more well-versed and competent in the art of argumentation and literary interpretation.

--I was able to improve my argumentation and reasoning skills--while writing. Hugo is very fantastic with tracing the line of reasoning you offer and then giving the right comments/feedback that will help you fix whatever mistake you made in your reasoning. My argumentation skills have dramatically increased from their level back in August--thanks to this class!

--I familiarized myself with the general structure of college-level academic readings/writings. This not only helped make the writing process less painful for me, but also helped me in being able to quickly scan other college-level readings/

--Learned about the general debate regarding anthropocentrism, ecocentrism and whatnot. Not super interested in environmentalism in stuff but this was a helpful way to get acquainted with the academics' thoughts on this phenomena.

I learned how to contribute to an academic discussion/debate in a meaningful way. I also learned how to structure my writing in a more logical way. Additionally, I learned how to break arguments down into their logical steps.
I improved my skills of writing essays, and how to research for essays.
I developed stronger writing skills.

This course helped me a good deal in trying to improve my writing skills overall I think, and I got to learn ways of analyzing arguments and writing papers that were new to me. It was also interesting to look at these perspectives on the ecological crisis. Even if it still takes me a ton of time and energy to write anything (I'm just personally slow), I feel at least that it can be done.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths were how straightforward and to the point Hugo is. The weakness is, I think, the slight lack of an emphasis on writing "style." We learned how to make rigorous and strong arguments, but did not really develop the "flair" that makes for an impressive writer.

This course is a good introduction to writing essays for people with little to no experience doing it. The teacher offers personal feedback, which helped me learn more than from my other courses. The writing peer tutor, Jack, was also very helpful. I think more guidance on a research topic for our third paper would have been helpful.

This course has many strengths. Hugo takes time to give detailed feedback on your papers and is always ready to answer your questions. The in-class discussions are also really great, and were my favorite part of the class. Hugo also relates the classwork with your personal interests very well. The only weakness is that I wish we could have gone over feedback in person (over zoom) rather than just getting comments on our documents. I think that discussing the comments on our paper would have been really helpful for writing future papers in the class.

I think the biggest strength is that it was very well structured and each assignment built from the last. The biggest weakness is probably the time commitment. I had to spend a lot of time writing and it ended up being one of my most time-consuming classes. To improve, I'd suggest that maybe the expectations be cut down a little bit, but it's not a big deal.

A big strength is the level of support from the professor outside of class, and the detailed and custom feedback on each and every assignment. Another strength is how we're eased into big essays, with drafts and psets that build up to final versions.

Strengths--Fantastic Instructor (Hugo) who is a very interesting, intelligent and understanding human being! He makes the course rather interesting with the questions he raises and class organization he plans. He is not rigid with plans (which some might consider a weakness since syllabus was frequently changed)--this allowed us to engage in several tasks during one meeting session--with a 5 minute break! Another strength is that the class essentially meets JUST on Thursday, with Tuesday being a brief 30 min session with Hugo and two of your group members. Speaking of which, the Tuesday PSET feedbacks were very helpful in guiding us through our papers and our ideas--Hugo is very amazing with giving practical feedback. Finally, the fact that we were able to choose whatever topic we wanted for Paper 3 and Paper 4 really made the whole research/writing/editing process worthwhile since we all, of course, chose topics we were super interested in!

Weakness--Thursday class times can be boring at times. The issue is not with Hugo, but sometimes the students. While it's supposed to be a discussion session, it's really not usual for most of the class to volunteer and raise a topic for discussion (or follow along a started discussion). Had we been able to do this, I think interesting debates/conversations would have transpired--an interesting experience. Second weakness is that we got very little feedback for Paper 4 (even though it was similar to Paper 3, which we received a tremendous deal of feedback for). Although this was because we had to submit P4 after Thanksgiving break and so had little time for feedback, it still meant that key mistakes in our paper did not get the chance to be corrected, hurting our grades somehow. Finally, I feel like Hugo did not give us much feedback regarding our writing style (word usage, emphasis, sentence structure). It's probably because he felt that we were all fine with that as Yalies, but I hope more specific comments regarding writing will be offered for future students.

Strengths: very involved instructor, detailed and informative feedback on writing, difficulty of essays increases gradually (not overwhelming), appropriate amount of reading (low enough to not be overwhelming and to allow students to dive deep into each one, high enough to allow exposure to a bunch of writing styles)

Weakness: This got better over the course of the semester, but it would be nice to consistently receive the week's problem set at an earlier point in the week.
I wish we had spent more time in full class discussions. A lot of the class was in breakout rooms with just one or two people and I would have liked more time discussing with the whole class.
This course did very well with developing my agrumentative writing as well as my writing as a whole. It was very engaging and the feed back was very good.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The problem sets succeeded. I don't think any of the styles of learning had a particular issue. The live discussions were engaging, and especially the frequent meetings with Hugo were very helpful.

The live virtual classroom and the virtual office hours offered the same information as if they had been done in-person and I learned a lot from them. Sometimes we were assigned asynchronous videos to watch. It was a bit hard to keep track of this. An improvement could be an e-mail telling us to watch the video.

I don't feel like I missed out on much by not meeting in person for this class. Hugo adapted our discussions to a virtual format very well, and we were given many opportunities to talk with our classmates and get to know them better.
I think the class worked fine virtually. All of our writing could be viewed and read at the same time.

The weekend and tuesday meetings to go over individual and group work, one-on-one and with every student, really helped in covid times. It made the class feel clearer, and like the professor was very involved and invested in our progress.

Successful: Tuesday PSET feedback sessions. Weekend PSET meetings
Could be improved: Not much, all that could be done was done in my opinion.

Successes: I really enjoyed the "whiteboard" google doc. This was used so that each student could write their own questions/responses in one spot that all other students could view. Also, a few minutes at the start of each class were dedicated to allowing students to talk to each other about things that aren't related to class (in breakout rooms). This was really nice because it gave me something to look forward to and also made the class feel more close-knit. There was also a short break part way through class to give students a chance to look away from the screen for a moment. This made it so much easier to pay attention.

Improvement: I can't think of anything that should be improved. I think the adjustments made for virtual learning in this class were very successful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if they are looking for a solid and interesting class for them to improve their writing.
Yes, it is an excellent introduction to writing no matter your prior experience in writing, because it gives you personalized feedback.

I highly recommend this course. It was a great class to take in my first semester of college in order to get acquainted with college writing, and it was also a very fun class. This class is perfect for people who like philosophical thinking, and have an interest in the environment.

I would reccomend this to someone who really wants to improve, because it was a really helpful class and I improved a lot. Although, I would also warn that it was pretty challenging (for me at least).
I would absolutely reccomend this course! Great class, great material, and great professor!
Sure, if you're interested in topics related to the environmental crisis. Also, if you're looking for a good WR credit from ENGL 114 seminars, I feel like this class is great for that!

Yes, I would highly recommend this course to any other student. Even if you aren't planning to do much writing in your future, this class is extremely helpful for increasing your confidence in your writing for other classes. It also makes it much easier to understand other academic papers when you read them. It is also just a really well made class.
I would recommend this course to another student because my writing certainly did improve.
I would definitely recommend this course to someone looking to improve their writing and interested in the particular field.
